title: When looking for a job within a large gaming industry company... advice? :) @Riot
body:
Hey guys!

I am a junior in college and I am looking into prepping my resume and any skills I'll need in the future (GIRLS ONLY LIKE GUYS WITH GOOD SKILLS) to get the right job I want. I have been looking at big gaming companies to see what opportunities they have available - so far I've been eyeing jobs at Riot, Twitch.TV, and ArenaNet. 

Here is a little background before I ask any specific questions:

As stated I am a junior in college. My degree is in Business Finance. I am looking into any job related to my degree, directly or indirectly. Positions I am interested in are any finance positions within a company, an account management position (ex: Twitch's Partnership Associate), or any marketing/sales/data analysis position (the data analysis position would probably have to be in line with money or using similar techniques that financial advisers use to analyse numbers).
Note: The position I am MOST interested in is twitch's partnership associate.

Now onto the questions:

What do I, as a fresh college graduate with a **bachelor's degree**, need to know in order to land one of these jobs? 
     -Data analysis/coding languages? (SQL, Python, etc)
     -Social Media Management?  
     
I want to know now what I can add to my resume that will lead to my success and growth within this industry. :)

If any Rioter's who deal with anything I've listed could comment that would be awesome! Or if anyone just has advice in general, I would love it! I am deeply considering learning SQL and maybe Python, but I do not want to invest in something that will be useless or outdated. I would appreciate in depth, detailed advice - I have heard all the basics, I want the specifics xD

<3

~HitYouInTheFace (◕‿◕✿)

Not happening. I've been a professional software developer for almost two decades now. I've programmed everything from assembly language on embedded and customize hardware systems to game consoles to super computers. I've used various assembly languages (RISC and CISC based processor architectures), C, C++, all but the earliest flavors of Fortran, Java, JavaScript, Perl, Python, Bash, Basic and others. Language is irrelevant. 

Python has pros and cons like any other language. It's good for some things, absolutely terrible for others. Java is good for somethings, not so good at others. C/C++ is good for some things, not so good at others. So on and so forth. It all depends on the problem and/or requirements. You're not going to write a device driver in python, and you're not going to write a web application in assembler.

A real software engineer analyzes the problem and determines which tools he or she needs in order to solve it. They don't try and shoehorn a particular language/framework/library into a solution just because they happen to really like a certain language or technology. That's how you wind up with problem projects that are error prone and difficult to maintain.

Back to the OP, if you're going for the finance angle the likelihood of you actually cutting any code outside of maybe spreadsheet macro is small. Most companies use standard financial management, analysis, and reporting software packages. If you're talking about deep analysis and modeling, you're probably going to need something stronger than a bachelor's for that, and becoming familiar with R (a popular statistical analysis language) probably wouldn't hurt either.
You might be interested in the chatroom RiotImminence.

It's a place where people who are looking to apply to riot can discuss things, usually about their applications. you could probably find people (rioters and people with similar experience to you who are applying to riot) who are willing to chat with you.

it's unlikely you'll start out by getting a job in the exact line of work of your choosing. i recommend being open about your career right out of college and finding a position that gets you the general skills to get you where your ultimate goal truly is.

Riot and Twitch both have jobs available that require 0 college experience/degree and that allow for growth in the company. Considering I will have a degree and some experience, I expect I will at least be a top candidate for some of those positions and I can rise from there. But you are correct - a job is a job and I will not be picky if the jobs I am offered will give me the experience I need. 

Thanks :)

You can be as incompetent as they come as long as you can brown nose your way in, this goes for most companies.

As an example, SOE during the making of Planetside 2 decided to grab a ton of interns for future jobs, according to the people they let go off, the place was all about butt sniffing to hide your incompetence, all the nerds who knew what they were doing and had attitudes at work were let go.

Work on your charisma rather than your job skills and you will go places.
